what: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
text: sigstats enables common mathematical operations / transformations applied sigverse style signatures / catalogues

title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
text: can install development version sigstats like :

title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
code: library(sigstats) library(sigstash) library(sigvis)  # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Create a model that represents a mix of SBS2 (40%) and SBS13 (60%) model <- c(SBS2 = 0.4, SBS13 = 0.6)  # Add selected signatures to the combined model combined_signatures <- sig_combine(signatures, model)  # Visualise result sig_visualise(   combined_signatures,    title = "Model",   subtitle = "Created by combining SBS2 (40%) and SBS13 (60%)"   ) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
text: sigstats helps add subtract catalogues/signatures

what: Reconstruct a mutation catalogue from a signature model
title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
text: often need reconstruct catalogue (tally) signature model.
code: # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Create a model that represents a mix of SBS2 (40%) and SBS13 (60%) model <- c(SBS2 = 0.4, SBS13 = 0.6)  # Create a new signature by combining SBS2 and SBS13 in ratios dictated by the above model signature <- sig_combine(signatures, model)  # Reconstruct a perfect catalogue describing what the mutational profile of a sample # with 200 mutations and the given signature model would look like reconstuction <- sig_reconstruct(signature, n=200)  # Visualise result sig_visualise(   reconstuction,    class = "catalogue",   title = "Reconstructed Catalogue",   subtitle = "Expected profile of a sample with 200 mutations: 40% from SBS2, 60% from SBS13"   ) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
text: ### Compute Similarity/Distance Measures
code: # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Compute common statistics: # e.g. Gini coefficient, Exponentiated Shannon Index, KL divergence, L1/L2/L3 Norms) stats <- sig_collection_stats(signatures)  # Print Stats head(stats) #>     id      gini shannon_index shannon_index_exp kl_divergence_from_uniform #> 1 SBS1 0.9480089      1.856082          6.398621                  2.7082657 #> 2 SBS2 0.9798792      1.218777          3.383048                  3.3455711 #> 3 SBS3 0.3268209      4.385754         80.298771                  0.1785939 #> 4 SBS4 0.6456680      3.809528         45.129134                  0.7548202 #> 5 SBS5 0.4063016      4.296474         73.440415                  0.2678738 #> 6 SBS6 0.8851745      2.718273         15.154126                  1.8460754 #>      l3_norm   l2_norm l1_norm l0_norm max_channel_fraction #> 1 0.41142780 0.4844887       1      96           0.37062390 #> 2 0.56614330 0.6231289       1      96           0.53513019 #> 3 0.06042455 0.1174484       1      96           0.02499156 #> 4 0.12333330 0.1852696       1      96           0.08026888 #> 5 0.07475926 0.1306525       1      96           0.04597922 #> 6 0.23115412 0.3114406       1      96           0.17879063 #>   shannon_index_exp_scaled l3_norm_scaled l2_norm_scaled l1_norm_scaled #> 1               0.06665230   0.0042857062    0.005046757     0.01041667 #> 2               0.03524008   0.0058973261    0.006490926     0.01041667 #> 3               0.83644553   0.0006294224    0.001223421     0.01041667 #> 4               0.47009514   0.0012847218    0.001929892     0.01041667 #> 5               0.76500432   0.0007787423    0.001360964     0.01041667 #> 6               0.15785548   0.0024078554    0.003244173     0.01041667 #>   l0_norm_scaled #> 1              1 #> 2              1 #> 3              1 #> 4              1 #> 5              1 #> 6              1  # Plot kl_divergence_from_uniform against exponentiated shannon index plot(   x = stats[["kl_divergence_from_uniform"]],    y = stats[["shannon_index_exp_scaled"]] ) signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Pairwise cosine similarity sim_df <- sig_collection_pairwise_stats(   signatures,   metric = "cosine_similarity",   format = "data.frame" ) head(sim_df) #>     S1    S2 cosine_similarity #> 1 SBS1  SBS2        0.02031489 #> 2 SBS1  SBS3        0.05372626 #> 3 SBS1  SBS4        0.02361321 #> 4 SBS1  SBS5        0.19426687 #> 5 SBS1  SBS6        0.77021158 #> 6 SBS1 SBS7a        0.04804510  # L2 (Euclidean) distance matrix dist_mat <- sig_collection_pairwise_stats(   signatures,   metric = "L2",   format = "matrix" )

title: Mathematical Operations and Transformations for Sigverse Signatures and Catalogues
text: Quantify well fitted model matches ground truth signature weights.
code: signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38") cosmic_signatures <- names(signatures)  observed <- c(SBS1 = 0.7, SBS5 = 0.3, SBS18 = 0) truth <- c(SBS1 = 0.6, SBS5 = 0.4, SBS18 = 0)  metrics <- sig_model_correctness(observed, truth, all_signatures = cosmic_signatures)  print(metrics) #> $fitting_error #> [1] 0.1 #>  #> $RMSE #> [1] 0.01591115 #>  #> $n_false_positives #> [1] 0 #>  #> $n_true_positives #> [1] 2 #>  #> $n_false_negatives #> [1] 0 #>  #> $n_true_negatives #> [1] 77 #>  #> $total_false_positive_contributions #> [1] 0 #>  #> $precision #> [1] 1 #>  #> $recall #> [1] 1 #>  #> $specificity #> [1] 1 #>  #> $mathews_correlation_coeff #> [1] 1 #>  #> $f1 #> [1] 1 #>  #> $balanced_accuracy #> [1] 1

title: Convert counts into fractions of total counts — compute_fraction_from_count

Add Two Catalogues — sig_add

Add Two Catalogues — sig_add
text: catalogue1, catalogue2 Two sigverse catalogue data.frames. See sigshared::example_catalogue(). Must type channel rows order.

what: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats
title: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats
text: Calculates specified pairwise metric unique pairs signatures sigverse collection. Supported metrics : cosine_similarity: returns values [0, 1], 1 indicates identical signatures L2: Euclidean distance signatures L1: Manhattan distance signatures

title: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats
code: sig_collection_pairwise_stats(   signatures,   metric = c("cosine_similarity", "L2", "L1"),   format = c("data.frame", "matrix") )

title: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats
text: signatures signature collection, either named list sigverse signature data.frames numeric matrix fractional values (contexts × signatures). Column names used signature IDs. metric Character; one c("cosine_similarity", "L2", "L1"). Determines pairwise metric compute. format Character; one c("data.frame", "matrix"). "data.frame" (default): returns long-format data.frame columns S1, S2, <metric>. "matrix": returns N×N symmetric numeric matrix pairwise metrics (dimnames = signature IDs). diagonal set 1 cosine similarity, 0 distance metrics.

title: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats
text: Depending format: data.frame data.frame one row per unique signature pair, columns S1, S2, chosen metric (named metric). matrix symmetric numeric matrix pairwise metrics, row column names corresponding signature IDs.

title: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats
text: input may supplied either : named list sigverse signature data.frames (validated via sigshared::assert_signature_collection()), numeric matrix (rows = mutation contexts, columns = signatures) non-NULL, unique column names. computing metric, column normalized sum 1 (via sigshared::compute_fraction()), ensuring minor rounding errors provided fractions affect results.

title: Compute Pairwise Similarity or Distance Metrics Between Signatures — sig_collection_pairwise_stats

what: Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats
title: Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats
text: Calculates panel descriptive statistics signature sigverse collection. metrics quantify different aspects mutational signature's shape — inequality, diversity, concentration, sparsity - useful comparing "flat", "focal", "distinctive" different signatures .

title: Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats
Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats
text: signatures sigverse signature collection (named list signature data.frames).

title: Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats
text: data.frame one row per signature columns computed metric.

title: Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats
text: signature, following metrics reported: gini: Measures inequality (0 = perfectly flat; 1 = weight one context). shannon_index: Entropy distribution (higher = uncertain/diverse). shannon_index_exp: Effective number active contexts (e.g., 96 = flat, 1 = peaked). shannon_index_exp_scaled: Fraction maximum possible diversity (0–1 scale). kl_divergence_from_uniform: Divergence uniform (flat) distribution. l1_norm: Total absolute weight (larger = mass fewer contexts). l2_norm: Magnitude vector; emphasizes focal peaks. l3_norm: Amplifies concentration even L2. l0_norm: Number non-zero contexts (also known L0 "norm"). true mathematical norm commonly used measure sparsity — many mutation channels contribute . value 0 means signature completely empty; higher value indicates active contexts. *_scaled variants: Norms divided number contexts allow cross-signature comparisons. max_channel_fraction: Highest single-context weight (equivalent infinity norm). function optimised speed (faster computing norm independently signature) returns data.frame one row per signature columns computed metric.

title: Compute Summary Statistics for a Signature Collection — sig_collection_stats

what: Add Signatures to a Combined Signature Model — sig_combine
title: Add Signatures to a Combined Signature Model — sig_combine
text: function takes signature collection model input adds selected signatures combined signature model. default output data.frame either sigverse signature format 'combined_signature_model' style depending format.

title: Add Signatures to a Combined Signature Model — sig_combine
code: sig_combine(   signatures,   model,   format = c("signature", "combined"),   verbose = FALSE )

title: Add Signatures to a Combined Signature Model — sig_combine
text: signatures sigverse signature collection. See (sigshared::example_signature_collection()) details. model named numeric vector representing contribution signature combined model. names correspond signatures, values represent contributions. sum values vector less equal 1. format character string indicating output format. "combined", function returns 'combined_signature_model' data.frame row represents contribution particular channel single signature (duplicate channels collapsed). "signature", function returns data sigverse signature format, representing novel signature created combining signatures collection according ratios described model. verbose enables detailed output messages (flag).

title: Add Signatures to a Combined Signature Model — sig_combine
text: data.frame 'combined_signature_model' style containing selected signatures modified fractions based model.

title: Add Signatures to a Combined Signature Model — sig_combine
Collapse to single signatures — sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature
text: Convert output sig_combine() simple sigverse signature object. useful want run maths signature derived model Note visualisation signature combination models, suggest directly using output sig_combine() sigvis::sig_visualise() sigvis::sig_make_interactive() run original signature contributions preserved

title: Collapse to single signatures — sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature
Collapse to single signatures — sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature
text: signature_combination dataframe produced sig_combine() represents combination multiple signatures known (exact) proportions - individual signature kept distinct make easy plot stackedbar

title: Collapse to single signatures — sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature
text: data.frame sigverse signature format

title: Collapse to single signatures — sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature
code: library(sigstash)  # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Create a model that represents a mix of SBS1 (40%) and SBS2 (60%) model <- c(SBS1 = 0.4, SBS2 = 0.6)  # Add selected signatures to the combined model combined_signatures <- sig_combine(signatures, model)  # Flatten the combined_signatures dataframe that keeps separate signatures signature <- sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature(combined_signatures)

what: Calculate Experimental P-Value Based on Bootstrap Contributions — sig_compute_experimental_p_value
title: Calculate Experimental P-Value Based on Bootstrap Contributions — sig_compute_experimental_p_value
text: single signature, calculate proportion bootstraps percentage contribution specified threshold. value represents 'experimental' P-value. example, P < 0.05, <5% chance signature contribution >= threshold chance.

title: Calculate Experimental P-Value Based on Bootstrap Contributions — sig_compute_experimental_p_value
Calculate Experimental P-Value Based on Bootstrap Contributions — sig_compute_experimental_p_value
text: bootstraps numeric vector describing percentage contributions single signature different bootstraps. threshold numeric value specifying minimum contribution threshold (typically 0.05). referred sparsity threshold.

title: Calculate Experimental P-Value Based on Bootstrap Contributions — sig_compute_experimental_p_value
text: proportion bootstraps contributions threshold. represents experimental p-value (referred sparsity p-value).

title: Calculate Experimental P-Value Based on Bootstrap Contributions — sig_compute_experimental_p_value

what: Calculate Cosine Matrix Between Two Signatures — sig_cosine_similarity
title: Calculate Cosine Matrix Between Two Signatures — sig_cosine_similarity
text: Computes cosine similarity pair signatures sigverse signature collection

title: Calculate Cosine Matrix Between Two Signatures — sig_cosine_similarity
Calculate Cosine Matrix Between Two Signatures — sig_cosine_similarity
text: signature1, signature2 sigverse signature data.frames. See sigshared::example_signature(). assume_sensible_input logical flag indicating whether skip validation checks input signatures. Enabling option can significantly speed cosine similarity calculation assuming inputs valid signature objects channels already sorted. option used performance critical assumptions can verified upstream.

title: Calculate Cosine Matrix Between Two Signatures — sig_cosine_similarity
text: number 0 1 representing cosine similarity

title: Calculate Cosine Matrix Between Two Signatures — sig_cosine_similarity
code: library(sigstash)  # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Compute cosine similarity between two signatures sig_cosine_similarity(signatures[["SBS1"]], signatures[["SBS2"]]) #> [1] 0.02031489

what: Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
title: Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
text: Calculates Gini coefficient, measure inequality concentration, sigverse signature catalogue. quantifies unevenly mutation probability mass distributed across contexts:

title: Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
text: signature sigverse signature catalogue data.frame.

title: Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
text: numeric value 0 1 representing Gini coefficient.

title: Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
text: 0: perfectly uniform distribution (e.g. 96 contexts equal) 1: total concentration single context Gini coefficient complements entropy-based measures like Shannon index capturing inequality distribution, rather uncertainty diversity. function uses unbiased version Gini coefficient, scaled K / (K - 1) K number mutation contexts. adjustment: Ensures Gini ranges 0 1 number contexts Makes measure comparable across signatures different numbers mutation types appropriate full probability distributions (mutation signatures)

title: Compute the Gini Coefficient of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_gini
code: library(sigstash) sigs <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  sig_gini(sigs[["SBS1"]])  # moderately peaked #> [1] 0.9480089 sig_gini(sigs[["SBS48"]]) # highly peaked, close to 1 #> [1] 0.9780847

what: Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
title: Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
text: Calculates Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence mutational signature uniform distribution. KL divergence quantifies much observed mutation context distribution (signature) deviates equal-weight, flat profile across contexts.

title: Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
text: signature sigverse signature data.frame. Must contain fraction column. base logarithmic base use (default natural log, exp(1)). Use 2 bits. pseudocount small positive number added term prevent log(0).

title: Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
text: single numeric value representing KL divergence uniform.

title: Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
text: value 0 indicates perfectly uniform signature. Higher values indicate peaked biased signatures. KL divergence commonly used measure "non-uniformity" "distinctiveness" mutation profiles. small pseudocount added avoid taking log zero context zero weight.

title: Compute KL Divergence from a Uniform Signature — sig_kl_divergence
code: library(sigstash) signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38") sbs3 <- signatures[["SBS3"]]  # Compute KL divergence (how far is SBS3 from flat?) sig_kl_divergence(sbs3) #> [1] 0.1785939  # Use base 2 (bits) sig_kl_divergence(sbs3, base = 2) #> [1] 0.2576565

what: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
title: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
text: Calculates L2 distance (Euclidean distance) two sigverse signatures catalogues. metric quantifies different distributions terms numeric values.

title: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
code: sig_l2_distance(   signature1,   signature2,   value = c("fraction", "count"),   scale = FALSE )

title: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
text: signature1, signature2 Two sigverse signatures catalogues. See sigshared::example_signature() sigshared::example_catalogue(). Must contain matching channel values identical order. value character string: "fraction" normalised signatures "count" raw catalogues. scale Logical. TRUE, divides L2 distance number elements. can help normalise distance values across signatures different dimensions.

title: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
text: single numeric value representing L2 distance.

title: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
text: vectors \( x \) \( y \), L2 distance : $$\|x - y\|_2 = \sqrt{\sum_i (x_i - y_i)^2}$$ smaller value indicates similar signatures, larger values indicate greater dissimilarity. often used simple fast alternative cosine similarity KL divergence.

title: Compute the L2 Distance Between Two Signatures or Catalogues — sig_l2_distance
code: library(sigstash)  signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38") s1 <- signatures[["SBS1"]] s2 <- signatures[["SBS5"]]  # Compute distance between two fractional signatures sig_l2_distance(s1, s2) #> [1] 0.4766606  # Compare catalogue-level distance (on raw counts) cat1 <- sig_reconstruct(s1, n = 100) cat2 <- sig_reconstruct(s2, n = 100) sig_l2_distance(cat1, cat2, value = "count") #> [1] 47.66606

what: Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
title: Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
text: Calculates L2 norm (Euclidean norm) sigverse signature catalogue. provides quantitative measure concentrated dispersed distribution .

title: Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
text: signature sigverse signature catalogue data.frame. value Character string, either "fraction" "count", indicating column compute norm . scale Logical. TRUE, divides norm number elements enable easier comparison across different signature sizes.

title: Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
text: single numeric value representing L2 norm.

title: Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
text: vector \( x \), L2 norm defined : $$\|x\|_2 = \sqrt{\sum_i x_i^2}$$ Interpretation: signature uniform distribution lower L2 norm. peaked signature (one dominant context) higher L2 norm. alternative entropy-based metrics (like Shannon index), useful quickly identifying signatures strong focal points.

title: Compute the L2 Norm of a Signature or Catalogue — sig_l2_norm
code: library(sigstash)  signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Compute L2 norm on fractional signature sig_l2_norm(signatures[["SBS1"]]) #> [1] 0.4844887  # Compare with a flatter signature sig_l2_norm(signatures[["SBS3"]]) #> [1] 0.1174484  # Compute on raw counts (requires a catalogue) cat1 <- sig_reconstruct(signatures[["SBS3"]], n = 100) sig_l2_norm(cat1, value = "count") #> [1] 11.74484

what: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
title: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
text: Calculates Lp distance (also known Minkowski distance) two sigverse signatures catalogues. generalizes various distance metrics depending choice p.

title: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
code: sig_lp_distance(   signature1,   signature2,   p,   value = c("fraction", "count"),   scale = FALSE )

title: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
text: signature1, signature2 Two sigverse signature catalogue data.frames. p numeric value ≥ 0 indicating order Lp norm compute. p = 0: counts number non-zero entries (true norm; useful sparsity). p = 1: Manhattan distance (sum absolute differences). p = 2: Euclidean (L2) distance. p = ∞: Chebyshev distance (maximum absolute difference). value Either "fraction" (default) "count" — determines column used comparison. scale Logical. TRUE, distance divided number contexts (.e. channels).

title: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
text: non-negative numeric value representing Lp distance two profiles.

title: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
text: function useful flexible distance computations comparing mutational signatures catalogues. channels must match order. default, distances computed using raw values. scale = TRUE, distance divided number mutation contexts allow comparisons across different signature types (e.g. SBS vs DBS).

title: Compute Lp Distance Between Two Signatures — sig_lp_distance
code: library(sigstash) sigs <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  sig_lp_distance(sigs[["SBS1"]], sigs[["SBS5"]], p = 1)  # L1 (Manhattan) #> [1] 1.677304 sig_lp_distance(sigs[["SBS1"]], sigs[["SBS5"]], p = 2)  # L2 (Euclidean) #> [1] 0.4766606 sig_lp_distance(sigs[["SBS1"]], sigs[["SBS5"]], p = 1, scale = TRUE) #> [1] 0.01747191

what: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
title: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
text: Computes suite evaluation metrics mutational signature fitting. function compares "observed" model (signature fitting) "truth" (true underlying signature contributions) reports standard accuracy metrics.

title: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
code: sig_model_correctness(observed, truth, all_signatures = NULL, validate = TRUE)

title: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
text: observed Numeric named vector. fitted model (signature weights). Names must signature IDs; values fractional contributions (typically sum 1). See sigshared::example_model(). truth Numeric named vector. true signature contributions; format observed. all_signatures Optional character vector. complete set possible signature IDs evaluated. NULL, inferred union names observed truth. validate Logical. TRUE (default), input vectors checked correct formatting, expanded/reordered needed. FALSE, user must ensure observed truth already aligned complete.

title: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
text: Named list metrics quantifying model correctness (see Details).

title: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
text: function returns named list : fitting_error Sum absolute differences observed truth, divided 2 (range: 0–1). RMSE Root mean squared error observed truth. n_false_positives Number signatures called present observed present truth. n_false_negatives Number signatures present truth missed observed. n_true_positives Number signatures correctly called present. n_true_negatives Number signatures correctly called absent. total_false_positive_contributions Sum weights assigned false positive signatures. precision Proportion detected signatures truly present (TP / (TP + FP)). recall Proportion true signatures detected (TP / (TP + FN)). specificity Proportion truly absent signatures detected (TN / (TN + FP)). mathews_correlation_coeff Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), balanced measure even imbalanced classes. f1 F1 score, harmonic mean precision recall. balanced_accuracy Average recall specificity. metric calculation, observed truth vectors expanded reordered (needed) include signatures all_signatures. signatures present observed truth assumed zero contribution. Presence/absence signature defined "present" weight > 0, "absent" weight == 0. signature, possible outcomes : True Positive (TP) Observed > 0 Truth > 0 (signature fitted truly present). False Positive (FP) Observed > 0 Truth == 0 (signature fitted truly present). False Negative (FN) Observed == 0 Truth > 0 (signature missed fitting truly present). True Negative (TN) Observed == 0 Truth == 0 (signature correctly called absent). Counts TP, FP, TN, FN used classification metrics. Division--zero results NA undefined metrics. Precision, recall, F1, MCC may comparable across datasets different class balances.

title: Quantify model correctness for signature deconvolution — sig_model_correctness
code: observed <- c(SBS1 = 0.7, SBS5 = 0.3, SBS18 = 0) truth <- c(SBS1 = 0.6, SBS5 = 0.4, SBS18 = 0) sig_model_correctness(observed, truth) #> $fitting_error #> [1] 0.1 #>  #> $RMSE #> [1] 0.08164966 #>  #> $n_false_positives #> [1] 0 #>  #> $n_true_positives #> [1] 2 #>  #> $n_false_negatives #> [1] 0 #>  #> $n_true_negatives #> [1] 1 #>  #> $total_false_positive_contributions #> [1] 0 #>  #> $precision #> [1] 1 #>  #> $recall #> [1] 1 #>  #> $specificity #> [1] 1 #>  #> $mathews_correlation_coeff #> [1] 1 #>  #> $f1 #> [1] 1 #>  #> $balanced_accuracy #> [1] 1 #>

what: Convert Signature Model to String Representation — sig_model_to_string
title: Convert Signature Model to String Representation — sig_model_to_string
text: function converts named numeric vector model representing signature contributions formatted string. default, contributions displayed percentages, options customize formatting. Unexplained portions model (.e., contributions accounted signatures) can optionally displayed.

title: Convert Signature Model to String Representation — sig_model_to_string
code: sig_model_to_string(   model,   signature_sep = " = ",   pair_sep = " | ",   show_percent = TRUE,   significant_digits = 2,   include_unexplained = TRUE,   unexplained_label = "?" )

title: Convert Signature Model to String Representation — sig_model_to_string
text: model named numeric vector representing contribution signature combined model. names correspond signatures, values represent contributions. sum values vector less equal 1. signature_sep character string used separate signature name value (default " = "). pair_sep character string used separate different signatures (default " | "). show_percent logical indicating whether format values percentages (default TRUE). significant_digits number significant digits display contributions (default 2). include_unexplained logical flag indicating whether include unexplained portion model (default TRUE). unexplained_label character string label unexplained portion model (default "?").

title: Convert Signature Model to String Representation — sig_model_to_string
text: string representing signature model contributions formatted according specified options.

title: Convert Signature Model to String Representation — sig_model_to_string
code: model <- c(SBS1 = 0.4, SBS2 = 0.6) sig_model_to_string(model) #> [1] "SBS2 = 60% | SBS1 = 40% | ? = 0%"  # Example with no unexplained portion, significant digits and percentages sig_model_to_string(   model,   significant_digits = 3,   show_percent = FALSE,   include_unexplained = FALSE   ) #> [1] "SBS2 = 0.6 | SBS1 = 0.4"

title: Autosomal context counts — sig_opportunities
text: Autosomal context counts

title: Autosomal context counts — sig_opportunities
Autosomal context counts — sig_opportunities
text: list context counts generated contextcounter

title: Autosomal context counts — sig_opportunities

what: Reconstruct a catalogue from a signature — sig_reconstruct
title: Reconstruct a catalogue from a signature — sig_reconstruct
text: Generates reconstructed substitution profile (catalogues) generated proportionally combining estimated contribution.

title: Reconstruct a catalogue from a signature — sig_reconstruct
Reconstruct a catalogue from a signature — sig_reconstruct
text: signature data.frame sigverse signature format. See sigshared::example_signature() details. n total number variants use reconstruction

title: Reconstruct a catalogue from a signature — sig_reconstruct
text: data.frame conforming sigverse catalogue format

title: Reconstruct a catalogue from a signature — sig_reconstruct
code: library(sigstash)  # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Create a model that represents a mix of SBS1 (40%) and SBS2 (60%) model <- c(SBS1 = 0.4, SBS2 = 0.6)  # Add selected signatures to the combined model combined_signatures <- sig_combine(signatures, model)  # Flatten the combined_signatures dataframe that keeps separate signatures signature <- sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature(combined_signatures)  # Reconstruct a perfect catalogue describing what the mutational profile of a sample # with 200 mutations and the given signature model would look like reconstuction <- sig_reconstruct(signature, n=200)  # Visualise Result # sig_visualise(reconstuction, class = "catalogue")

title: Signature renormalisation — sig_renormalise
text: Transform signature look like called different pipeline/genome/organism account different 'mutation opportunites'

title: Signature renormalisation — sig_renormalise
Signature renormalisation — sig_renormalise
text: signature sigverse style signature data.frames. See sigshared::example_signature(). opportunities_original named vector mutation opportunities context. See sig_opportunities(). opportunities_new named vector mutation opportunities context. See sig_opportunities().

title: Signature renormalisation — sig_renormalise
text: sigverse style signature data.frame. See sigshared::example_signature().

title: Signature renormalisation — sig_renormalise
code: opps <- sig_opportunities() signature <- data.frame(   channel = c("A[C>G]G", "A[C>G]C", "A[C>G]T"),   type = c("C>G", "C>G", "C>G"),   fraction = c(0.4, 0.1, 0.5) )  # Convert genome signature to panel signature (TSO 500) sig_renormalise(   signature,   opps$GRCh38_genome_trinucleotide_autosomal,   opps$GRCh38_tso500_trincucleotide_autosomal ) #>   channel type   fraction #> 1 A[C>G]G  C>G 0.62127379 #> 2 A[C>G]C  C>G 0.08744164 #> 3 A[C>G]T  C>G 0.29128457

what: Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
title: Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
text: Computes Shannon diversity index sigverse signature. metric quantifies entropy uncertainty associated distribution mutation contexts signature, based relative fraction mutations context.

title: Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
text: signature sigverse signature data.frame. See sigshared::example_signature(). exponentiate Logical. TRUE, returns exponentiated Shannon index (effective number contexts).

title: Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
text: numeric value: either Shannon index (entropy) exponentiated index (effective diversity).

title: Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
text: default, function returns Shannon index entropy value. exponentiate = TRUE, function returns exponentiated Shannon index, also known effective number contexts (Hill number order 1). makes interpretation intuitive: signature concentrated entirely single context exponentiated index 1. perfectly uniform signature (equal weight across 96 SBS contexts) exponentiated index 96. biological terms, exponentiated Shannon index answers: "many equally frequent mutation contexts give level diversity?"

title: Calculate the Shannon Diversity Index for a Signature — sig_shannon
code: library(sigstash) signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38") sbs3 <- signatures[["SBS3"]] sbs48 <- signatures[["SBS48"]]  # Shannon entropy sig_shannon(sbs3) #> [1] 4.385754  # Exponentiated Shannon index (effective # of active contexts) sig_shannon(sbs3, exponentiate = TRUE) #> [1] 80.29877  # Compare with a highly focused signature sig_shannon(sbs48, exponentiate = TRUE) #> [1] 2.681695

title: Subtract Signatures/Catalogues — sig_subtract
text: Subtracts signature2 signature1 returns result.

title: Subtract Signatures/Catalogues — sig_subtract
Subtract Signatures/Catalogues — sig_subtract
text: signature1, signature2 sigverse signature/catalogue data.frames. See sigshared::example_signature() sigshared::example_catalogue().

title: Subtract Signatures/Catalogues — sig_subtract
text: data.frame representing sigverse signature.

title: Subtract Signatures/Catalogues — sig_subtract
Sum a Collection Catalogues — sig_sum
text: Sums list sigverse catalogues, two individual catalogues, single result.

title: Sum a Collection Catalogues — sig_sum
Sum a Collection Catalogues — sig_sum
text: catalogues named list sigverse catalogue data.frames. See sigshared::example_catalogue_collection()

title: Sum a Collection Catalogues — sig_sum
text: sigverse catalogue data.frame representing total. See sigshared::example_catalogue().

title: Sum a Collection Catalogues — sig_sum
text: function useful aggregating catalogues across samples replicates. need add two catalogues, may use %+% operator instead.

title: Sum a Collection Catalogues — sig_sum
code: library(sigstash)  # Load a signature collection signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Reconstruct catalogues for two pure samples (each with 100 mutations) catalogue1 <- sig_reconstruct(signatures[['SBS3']], n = 100) catalogue2 <- sig_reconstruct(signatures[['SBS4']], n = 100)  # Sum catalogue1 and  catalogue2 catalogue_sum <- catalogue1 %+% catalogue2  # Sum a collection collection <- list(cat1 = catalogue1, cat2 = catalogue2) collection <- sig_sum(collection)

title: Summarise Signature Bootstraps — sig_summarise_bootstraps
text: function computes summary statistics signature-level bootstraps, including quantiles, min/max contribution proportions, experimental p-value.

title: Summarise Signature Bootstraps — sig_summarise_bootstraps
Summarise Signature Bootstraps — sig_summarise_bootstraps
text: bootstraps data frame containing bootstrap results sigverse-style format. See sigshared::example_bootstraps() details. threshold minimum proportion mutations must explained signature considered present bootstrap. threshold used calculating experimental p-value via sig_compute_experimental_p_value(). outliers_as_strings Logical. Return outliers character vector '|' delimited strings rather list-column (ignored return_dataframe = FALSE). Can customise delimiter using delim argument

title: Summarise Signature Bootstraps — sig_summarise_bootstraps
text: data frame containing following columns: signatures Names signatures. quantiles, iqr, min, max,outlier_thresholds Statistical summary columns (quantiles, min, max) contribution proportions across bootstraps. outliers either list column character '|' outlier strings (depending outliers_as_strings argument p_value Computed experimental p-value signature, based threshold.

title: Summarise Signature Bootstraps — sig_summarise_bootstraps
code: library(sigshared) bootstraps <- example_bootstraps() sig_summarise_bootstraps(bootstraps, threshold = 0.05) #>   signatures  min  max     q1     q3   iqr median n outlier_low_threshold #> 1 Signature1 0.30 0.44 0.3350 0.4050 0.070  0.370 2                 0.230 #> 2 Signature2 0.50 0.69 0.5475 0.6425 0.095  0.595 2                 0.405 #> 3 Signature3 0.01 0.06 0.0225 0.0475 0.025  0.035 2                -0.015 #>   outlier_high_threshold outliers p_value #> 1                  0.510              0.0 #> 2                  0.785              0.0 #> 3                  0.085              0.5
